Award.AbstractNarration:
Nature has intrinsic handedness because of the weak interaction, but the difference between the left- and right-handed cases is barely discernible in atomic and nuclear interactions. Understanding its strength in nuclei is possible through measurements that require francium atoms so cold that they barely move. They show the effects of the handedness, from the anapole moment, when they are set to oscillate, and their frequency of oscillation changes with the handedness. The researchers will study the weak interaction, the force responsible for the beginning of the solar cycle, inside the francium nucleus. The atoms, made in the accelerator at TRIUMF Vancouver Canada, will be held on a laser trap, excited with microwaves and generate signals that show the handedness of nature.

This international effort, with active participants from the USA, Canada, and Mexico, as well as Australia and China, is an example of multinational collaboration that is enabling investigations at the frontier of physics. The research will allow US graduate and undergraduate students to obtain valuable global perspectives in science, and be educated in the boundary between atomic molecular and optical physics and nuclear physics. In addition, undergraduates from Mexico, through a program with the Sociedad Mexicana de Fisica, will participate in the summer at TRIUMF. The recently commissioned Francium Trapping Facility at TRIUMF is available for visits by the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While people do not feel the weak force in the same way they feel electricity or gravity, its effects are universal. The weak force allows stuff to become unglued and form new elements through decay—the sun, for example, is powered through deuterium fuel, which is generated via weak force mediated interactions that convert protons into neutrons.  The weak force is elusive as it operates between objects that are separated by miniscule distances deep within atomic nuclei. Fortunately one of its identifying signatures is that the weak interaction has handedness; it distinguishes between right handed and left handed in the microscopic world.Parity symmetry---the proposition that nature cannot tell left from right handedness---is upheld by the strong and electromagnetic forces but not by the weak force. That is, for parity to be “conserved,” then it would make no difference in our measurements whether we were observing an interaction among particles directly or by viewing them in a mirror. For the strong and electromagnetic forces this is true but not for the weak force. 

The anapole moment is a manifestation of the weak force inside an atomic nucleus, and its detection is by looking at atomic parity non conservation (APNC) processes that involve both the electrons and the nucleus. Francium is expected to have a large anapole moment and its measurement will help understand better how the weak force operates inside a nucleus. This grant has allowed the use of an apparatus that we have built to trap and cool francium atoms (The Francium Trapping Facility) on line with the TRIUMF accelerator in Vancouver, Canada. Our work during this grant period has been focused on better understanding the francium atom, with its 87 protons, and how it changes when it has more or less neutrons (different isotopes). 

The number of neutrons affects the size of the nucleus. It can increase or decrease the distribution of charge (charge radius) and it can modify the magnetic properties of the nucleus (nuclear magnetization radius). Both properties can be measured by precisely looking at the excitation of the atom when laser light of known frequency is resonant with a transition. The changes in the frequencies are minuscule, but careful measurements have provided significant differences that ensure the future success of the weak interaction studies looking at APNC in francium.

The francium trapping facility apparatus is now fully functional. It has been made more robust to withstand the continuous use during beam time. The transfer of the trapped atoms from the capture chamber to the science chamber, where the environmental control is high, routinely reaches more than 50% efficiency. 

Graduate and undergraduate students have been trained in the disciplines of atomic, optical, nuclear, and particle physics. The efforts are part of a larger international group of scientists, the FrPNC collaboration that includes participants from the United States, Canada, Australia, China, and Mexico.
